intro: Acalypha commersoniana f. colorata, commonly known as the Crimson Cudweed, is a striking ornamental plant native to South America. It is characterized by its vibrant, colorful bracts that range from red to orange, which are often mistaken for flowers. The plant has alternate, heart-shaped leaves with a smooth texture and a slightly waxy appearance. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil. Its unique foliage makes it a popular choice for garden landscapes and container planting.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha commersoniana f. colorata is primarily native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly Brazil, Peru, and Bolivia. This plant thrives in humid, lowland areas with rich, well-drained soils. It is commonly found in the understorey of tropical rainforests and along riverbanks. The species is known for its striking, colorful bracts that attract various pollinators. Its natural distribution is largely restricted to these specific ecological zones within the Amazon and Andean regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha commersoniana f. colorata was mainly introduced to enhance ornamental value in gardens and landscapes due to its vibrant foliage. Its introduction has led to its cultivation in various parts of the world, including the Caribbean, Southeast Asia, and parts of the United States.
